meanings.definition: To move or be forced below something else, especially when two tectonic plates collide.
meanings.sent1: During the earthquake, the oceanic plate started to subduct beneath the continental plate.
meanings.sent2: The geologist explained how tectonic plates can subduct under one another.
meanings.sent3: The sandwich tried to subduct under the heavy book in my bag, causing a messy situation.
meanings.sent4: As the pressure increased, the metal sheet began to subduct under the weight of the massive rock.
meanings.sent5: The idea of the submarine subducting into the depths of the ocean fascinated the young explorer.

meanings.definition: To take away or deduct something from a total.
meanings.sent1: I had to subduct the cost of the damaged item from the final bill.
meanings.sent2: The teacher will subduct points for late submissions of assignments.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel tried to subduct nuts from the pile hidden by the diligent squirrel.
meanings.sent4: The magician seemed to subduct the coin from the volunteer's hand with a swift movement.
meanings.sent5: The accountant needed to subduct the expenses to calculate the net profit accurately.
